title_en: Is an LCBO strike possible this summer?
summary_en:
A summer strike at LCBO is possible due to unsuccessful negotiations with the government on a new contract.
More than 9,000 workers, represented by the OPSEU trade union, intend to strike from June 12 to 15.
Negotiations on a new contract have been ongoing since March, and the main stumbling block is job security guarantees.
Prime Minister Doug Ford has announced the approval of the sale of beer, wine, cider and cocktails in convenience stores and grocery stores by 2026.
LCBO remains the only place where strong alcoholic beverages can be purchased, and remains a wholesaler.
Both sides remain at the negotiating table, and the mediator is due to join the talks next week.

title_en: A new demonstration calls for increased investment in public education in Asturias
summary_en:
The educational community is demanding better funding for public schools and shorter school hours in elementary schools.
This is the second time in a month that a public school has taken to the streets to demand an education advisor.
The march, called by CCOO, SUATEA, UGT and CSIF-ANPE, accuses them of violating union unity and putting teachers' demands in the hands of parent associations.
The organizers threaten to intensify the protests and go on strike if the Board of Education does not sit down at the negotiating table.
The requirements include a new staffing agreement, provision of staffing centers, ending part-time work and reducing the number of students in schools.
The organizers also demand a reduction in the teaching day of teachers from 25 to 23 hours per week and a lighter workload for people over 55 years old.
They call for the introduction of a lifelong learning program for teachers and the creation of a network of children's schools that will not worsen women's working conditions.

title_en: Drivers delivering fuel to garage yards will go on strike
summary_en:
Drivers of tanker trucks delivering garage fuel and jet fuel are planning a strike over a salary dispute.
Members of the Unite union based at the Stanlow refinery will be fired on June 6-8 and 13-15.
Drivers at Hoyer, renamed Oxalis, say their salaries are significantly lower than those of their counterparts in other parts of the country.
Oxalis stated that it has contingency plans in place so that its operations can continue.
Unite General Secretary Sharon Graham says Oxalis treats its Stanlow drivers like second-class workers.
Oxalis has offered drivers a 19% pay raise over two years, but further increases in costs put jobs at risk.
Further negotiations with the union are planned, and Oxalis is confident that all operations will continue in the event of strikes.

title_en: Acerinox employees have announced a 120-day strike in the name of reconciliation
summary_en:
Acerinox employees in Los Barrios have been on strike for 120 days without getting paid.
The plant producing and exporting stainless steel has been shut down.
The management of the company and the committee failed to conclude an agreement on a new employment agreement.
More than 2,000 families are participating in the strike, including Acerinox staff and contractor families.
The mediation of the Junta of Andalusia in the labor conflict failed to unblock it.
Employees are fighting for family reconciliation and protection of free time, not just for money.
Salary review is a fair thing that should be done by law.
Acerinox has released a statement that the plant will operate in three shifts instead of the usual five.
The workers do not fully understand the logic of the management and believe that the company should negotiate a reasonable agreement.
